chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Government should ensure that every person can obtain essential healthcare—preventive, primary, emergency, and mental-health services—without facing medical bankruptcy or being denied for preexisting conditions. Rather than dictating a single model, it should set clear national standards, subsidize coverage for those who cannot afford it, and use transparent payment and quality rules to curb waste and price gouging. Private plans, employer coverage, and community-based providers should remain part of the system, competing and partnering within those rules so access, choice, and fiscal sustainability improve together.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Government should guarantee a universal, affordable baseline of evidence-based healthcare—especially preventive, primary, mental-health, and emergency care—so no one faces medical bankruptcy and communities stay healthy and productive. That guarantee should be delivered with fiscal discipline through transparent pricing, measurable outcomes, and strong oversight that rewards value and controls costs. Within clear national standards, implementation should rely on accountable public–private partnerships with employers, local clinics, and community and faith-based organizations, preserving individual choice and room for private options and innovation.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Government should ensure every person can get basic, affordable care—preventive, primary, mental-health, and emergency services—so no one faces medical bankruptcy and public health is protected. That guarantee should set clear national standards and protections for seniors, veterans, and people with disabilities, while letting states and local communities choose practical delivery models that work for them. Costs should be controlled through price transparency, competition where possible, and strict anti-fraud oversight, with room for private plans and employer coverage for those who want more than the baseline.
